abstracts.cdata!:
The National Water Rehabilitation, the
            First Multi-State, and the Small Towns Water Supply projects
            were selected for this cluster assessment in order to
            evaluate the reasons for the failure of the Bank's
            assistance to the Nigerian water supply sector in the
            1979-2004 period.  These projects represent a clear
            evolution in the scope of World Bank lending: the first
            project was nationwide and concentrated on procurement and
            installation of equipment in selected water systems in each
            of the 36 Nigerian states and the National Federal
            Territory; the second project was restricted to two states
            (Kaduna and Katsina); and the third project directly
            assisted 16 small towns. This assessment rated the outcome
            of the National Water Rehabilitation Project as highly
            unsatisfactory, sustainability highly unlikely, negligible
            institutional development Impact, and unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower.  For the First
            Multi-State Water Supply Project, the assessment concurred
            with the completion report, except that the PPAR rated the
            outcome as moderately satisfactory. The PPAR rated the
            outcome of the Small Towns Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project as satisfactory with likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impact and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            There are three principal lessons: First, the targets under
            the MDGs for water supply and sanitation, focusing only on
            service coverage and access, need to be expanded to include
            the reliability and quality of water supplies.  Second,
            effective coordination between central, state and local
            governments requires demand-driven approaches where the
            consumers have the initiative. Third, maintenance merits
            priority over new works.
